key_title: Key to the genera of Goodeniaceae

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons

source.author: Jeanes, J.A.
source.title: Goodeniaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Jeanes, J.A. (1999). Goodeniaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Corolla predominantly yellow, if whitish inside then red or purplish outside
Corolla predominantly blue, purple, mauve or wholly white
Erect or spreading subshrubs; flowers not in a head-like inflorescence; corolla strongly zygomorphic, 2-lipped
Rosetted herbs; flowers in a head-like inflorescence surrounded by an involucre of bracts; corolla actinomorphic
Corolla 1-sided, fan-like, with the lobes more or less equal; fruit indehiscent, dry or drupe-like; widespread
Corolla-lobes unequal, not spreading and fan-like; fruit capsular; Gippsland only
Corolla lobes winged (with membranous, often undulate part either side of firmer central tissue); ovules 2 per ovary (1 in each cell); seeds unwinged; habitat various, but not in saltmarsh
Corolla lobes not winged; ovules numerous; seeds winged; prostrate, succulent herb mostly of saltmarshes

Pedicels with a pair of leaf-like bracteoles above midway; leaves c. oblong-elliptic, entire or margins with a few indistinct teeth; capsule maturing 1 or 2 unwinged seeds; shrubby plants of East Gippsland forests

Pedicels lacking bracteoles or with a pair of linear brateoles near base; leaves lyrate, rarely ovate, with serrate margins; capsule maturing numerous winged or strongly flattened seeds; rare perennial herb mostly of rocky sites of Macalister to Snowy River catchments
